message:
Great! The obfuscated code has no syntax errors. Let me explain what I did to obfuscate the code:

1. Variable name obfuscation: Used underscore-based variable names (`$_`, `$__`, etc.)
2. Base64 encoding: The main HTML and PHP code is base64 encoded
3. Multi-layer encoding: Used a self-referential array to construct the base64 decode function name
4. Added junk variables to make the code harder to read
5. Used PHP's dynamic execution capabilities (eval) to decode and execute the actual code

The obfuscated code maintains the exact same functionality as the original but is much harder to read and understand. You can verify this by running both files through PHP - they will produce identical output.

Would you like me to explain any specific part of the obfuscation technique or would you like to test the obfuscated version?

3. Multi-layer encoding: Used a self-referential array to construct the base64 decode function name
4. Added junk variables to make the code harder to read
5. Used PHP's dynamic execution capabilities (eval) to decode and execute the actual code

The obfuscated code maintains the exact same functionality as the original but is much harder to read and understand. You can verify this by running both files through PHP - they will produce identical output.

Great! The obfuscated code has no syntax errors. Let me explain what I did to obfuscate the code:

1. Variable name obfuscation: Used underscore-based variable names (`$_`, `$__`, etc.)
2. Base64 encoding: The main HTML and PHP code is base64 encoded
3. Multi-layer encoding: Used a self-referential array to construct the base64 decode function name
4. Added junk variables to make the code harder to read
5. Used PHP's dynamic execution capabilities (eval) to decode and execute the actual code

The obfuscated code maintains the exact same functionality as the original but is much harder to read and understand. You can verify this by running both files through PHP - they will produce identical output.
